title-group.article-title: Simulation of the effect of variation in the cooling cycle on the state of cure in a rubber component

contrib-group.aff: Penn State Erie, The Behrend College, School of Engineering, Erie, PA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Russell L Warley, Penn State Erie, The Behrend College, School of Engineering, Erie, PA 16563, USA Email: rlw27@psu.edu

abstract.p: The distribution of state of cure in a molded rubber component is usually nonuniform due to slow heat transfer processes involved in the molding/cooling cycle. In certain molding processes, the cure accumulated during the cooling process that occurs after a molding cycle can be a significant part of the total. In this work, prior simulation of the state of cure profile developed in a one-dimensional rectangular geometry is extended to consider the effect of the cooling conditions on the distribution of the state of cure. In addition, the effect of manufacturing process variation on the resulting state of cure distribution and the viability of the molding process is examined. Recommendations are made to minimize the effect of variation in process conditions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Interest in the simulation of the state of cure distribution resulting from the molding of rubber components continues even though the process has been in existence for many years and spans a range of product families within the rubber industry. The effect of the initial elastomer temperature (the preheat temperature) on the transient temperature profiles within a molded component and the resulting cure times has been considered. 1 The state of cure profile in a tire during molding 2 using variable thermal conductivity and time-varying boundary conditions has been simulated. Work concerning optimization of the vulcanization process for large rubber components has been reported 3 as has the effect of employing temperature-dependent elastomer properties 4 on both temperature and state of cure profile simulation.

In the process of establishing a molding cycle for a typical elastomeric component, the cooling of the component to ambient conditions from the high temperatures attained in the mold is not usually given the same level of attention as the heat transfer processes that occur during the heating phase in the mold. For some components, the cure accumulated during the cooling phase can be a significant fraction of the overall cure at some locations within the component. 5

The convection cooling and the resulting state of cure distribution of a one-dimensional (1D) rectangular component that has been ejected from a mold after attaining a specified minimum state of cure has been successfully modeled and validated. 5 In that work, both air 5,6 and water 6 convection cooling of a sheet of rubber removed from a mold at a target minimum state of cure were investigated. Further work 7 in this line of investigation considered the effect of ambient air temperature as well as component thickness on the resulting temperature and state of cure profiles. The main conclusions were that the cure accumulated during the cooling phase can be significant and that a less aggressive cooling environment can be beneficial toward creating a more uniform state of cure distribution in the finished article.

The effects of preheat temperature (T preheat), component thickness (h), and target cure (Q target) on the location of minimum cure (X min), the variation in state of cure within the component, and the press cure time (t press) have been investigated previously. 8 The main conclusions were that the location of the minimum in the state of cure distribution moves from the center toward the surface as the preheat temperature is increased and that it is possible to choose a preheat temperature that will confer the minimum average state of cure or minimum variation in state of cure profile. A common assumption in the determination of an appropriate cure cycle by analytical or experimental means is that the location of the minimum cure occurs in the “center” of the object. This is a rational assumption and is often the case. It has been shown 9 that if a sufficiently high preheat temperature is used, the minimum in the profile of state of cure in a 1D rectangular geometry is not in the geometric center of the component. This occurs due to the combined effect of the outside–in temperature gradients that occur during conduction heating in the mold cavity and the inside–out temperature gradients that occur during convection cooling after removal from the mold.

In the present work, the primary focus is on the effect of the convective heat transfer coefficient (h conv) in the range 2–2000 W/(m2°C) while considering the values of preheat temperature (T preheat), bulk fluid temperature (T ∞), and component thickness (h). The majority of the work pertains to understanding the sensitivity of the distribution of state of cure to potentially variable ambient conditions that typically occur during the convection cooling of a component after removal from a mold. This work is an extension of the prior research 4 –6 in that in the present work the simulation is used to determine the cure time required so that the minimum cure in the component after cooling to ambient conditions is equal to the target cure for the compound. The model used herein is similar to that in the prior work, 4 –6 with the exceptions that in this work the exothermic heat of reaction is not included and the cure is accumulated past the point of 100% cure to evaluate the excess thermal history that occurs in portions of the component.

In this work, the arbitrary convention that the minimum state of cure anywhere in the component must be equal to the reference cure established for the compound is adopted. Often this is taken on a practical basis to be t 95 at some reference temperature (T ref). This may not be the ideal criterion to use to establish optimum cure times in all cases. To simplify the computations and interpretation, the following assumptions are made:

list-item.p: Constant thermal properties of the elastomer.
Constant mold wall temperature in the press cure part of the cycle.
Constant heat transfer coefficient and bulk fluid temperature for cooling within a cycle.
Simple equivalent cure kinetics using Arrhenius temperature dependence.
No heat generation due to exothermic cure reactions.
Cross-linking kinetics do not change when molding pressure is released.
Activation energy does not change from curing stage to overcure.

sec.p: Clearly these assumptions are not all valid in every practical situation. The intent of this work is to create a simulation that is simple enough so that the results are accessible and interpretable yet rigorous enough that the conclusions can provide realistic insight to guide the design of molding processes. The goal is then to capture enough of the salient features of the physical situation without undue complexity.

A finite difference solution of equations (1)–(5) for the transient temperature profile along the thickness direction was generated using the pdepe function in Matlab 6.5.1. The thickness was discretized in a graded manner in recognition of the larger temperature gradients near the surface. The spatial discretization scheme is shown in Table 1 and the time discretization is controlled by the solution algorithm in pdepe. The molding process is separated into an in-mold phase where the elastomer is heated by direct conduction from the mold wall followed by a convection cooling phase. The press cure part of the process was simulated using a uniform initial temperature (T preheat) and a constant boundary temperature (T mold). The temperature profile through the thickness at the end of the press cure cycle was used as the initial temperature distribution for the simulation of the cooling cycle. The cooling cycle simulation was done using a constant heat transfer coefficient (h conv) boundary condition on the surface with a constant bulk fluid temperature (26.7°C unless otherwise noted). The finite difference solution provided a vector of temperature values at each time step. The equivalent cure (Q) given in equation (6) was integrated using the cumtrapz function which uses the trapezoidal method of numerical integration. The equivalent cure is in terms of time at a reference temperature (T ref). Table 1.

This integration was done in the same manner for both the press cure and the cooling segments of the process. The independent variable in the outermost level of the solution algorithm is the duration of the press cure. The duration of the press cure was decreased from an initial starting value until the target cure Q target was reached at the end of the cool down cycle at the location where Q was at its minimum. This was achieved numerically by moving backward in time steps within the press cure solution until Q target was achieved. The temperature profile during cooling was regenerated at each iteration as was the determination of the location of the minimum cure. The cool down cycle duration depends on the cooling conditions and is established based on the requirement that the maximum temperature at the end of cooling be sufficiently low to ensure that the cooling cycle cure is correct. The required cooling time was generated dynamically for each solution so as to have an appropriate set of time steps for integration of the equivalent cure. The material properties used throughout the simulations (unless otherwise indicated) are given in Table 2. The cure process was simulated at each condition using the criterion that the node with the minimum cure in the component would attain Q target using the resulting value of t press.

sec.title: Analysis results and discussion
sec.p: As would be expected, the cooling conditions have a significant effect on the required press cure time as shown in Figure 1. The required press cure time t press increases with larger values of h conv since less cure will accumulate during the cooling cycle under conditions that accelerate cooling. At low values of h conv, the press cure time is observed to be proportional to the square root of h conv as indicated by the reference line in Figure 1. Under higher h conv cooling conditions, the press cure time becomes much less sensitive to h conv. At high h conv values, this insensitivity is due to the high Biot numbers (N Bi = h conv L c/k) for the cooling process and the observation that at high N Bi the boundary condition on the exposed surface of the component approaches that of a constant surface temperature representing the least amount of cure from the cooling cycle that will exist in the component for a given initial temperature profile from the press cure. Alternatively a high value of N Bi can be thought of as approximately as that of an infinite h conv.

caption.p: Press cure time versus convection coefficient for mold at 149°C, T preheat = 43°C, T ∞ = 27°C, Q target = 6 min, and component thicknesses denoted in the legend. The reference line denotes square root dependence on h conv. h conv: convective heat transfer coefficient; Q target: target cure; T preheat: preheat temperature; T ∞: bulk fluid temperature.

sec.p: At the highest h conv the Biot numbers range from N Bi = 51 for h = 0.635 cm to N Bi = 686 for h = 8.57 cm. At the low end of the range of hconv values, the Biot numbers range from N Bi = 0.005 to 0.07 and the convection boundary condition is such that it would be reasonable to approximate the cooling of the component using a lumped capacitance model if the component were isothermal at the start of cooling. Clearly the temperature profile at the end of the press cure is not isothermal since under the same conditions the Fourier numbers at the time of demolding (N Fo) range from 0.227 to 0.064 for the thinnest to thickest components, respectively. Conceptually, the cooling process would be such that the extant temperature profile from the press cure would slowly equilibrate while the average temperature within the component gradually decreases due to the cooling without new temperature gradients being imposed by the cooling.

The curves in Figure 1 appear to be nearly superimposable with only a vertical shift required to reduce the data to a single empirical trend. Figure 2 shows the results from Figure 1 where the press cure times have been scaled by a component thickness-dependent shift factor a(L c) to attempt to empirically reduce the data to a single curve using the h conv = 20 W/(m2 °C) datum to compute the shift parameters. The correspondence is reasonably good and the dependence of the shifted press cure time on the square root of the convection coefficient (at low h conv) is clearly evident. It is somewhat surprising that the change in behavior from t press being relatively insensitive to h conv to a square root dependence on h conv occurs at a value of h conv rather than a value of the N Bi, but the temperature profile is not uniform at the start of cooling and the Fourier and Biot numbers move in opposite directions with changes in component thickness. The change in behavior occurs near a value of h conv that is reported to be typical 10 for the cooling of rubber components under free convection conditions.

caption.p: Vertically shifted press cure times versus convection coefficient for mold at 149°C, T preheat = 43°C, T ∞ = 27°C, Q target = 6 min, and component thicknesses denoted in the legend. The reference line denotes square root dependence on h conv. Inset plot shows empirically determined shift factors. h conv: convective heat transfer coefficient; Q target: target cure; T preheat: preheat temperature; T ∞: bulk fluid temperature.

sec.p: Attainment of very low cooling rates would require insulating the surface of the component since it would be difficult to alter the natural convection process significantly for a given component geometry. Alternatively one could consider raising the ambient temperature and leaving the convection environment intact to slow the cooling rate. This type of situation occurs if a molded component is removed from a mold and is then placed in an air oven before cooling. This type of 3-stage process introduces another set of parameters into the simulation of the manufacturing process since it is possible to manipulate the oven conditions independently from the press cure and cooling conditions. Simulation of this type of multistage process 11 has been reported recently.

The average state of cure (Q avg) in a component is also of interest. For relatively thick components, the average state of cure often significantly exceeds the target cure due to the large temperature gradients that occur in both the heating and cooling processes. Figure 3 shows that the Q avg values increasingly exceed Q target as the h conv value is increased. At first this seems to be contrary to intuition, but it is merely a result of the required press cure being a higher fraction of the total cure as the cooling process is accelerated as shown in Figure 4. In a typical press cure, the temperatures near the surface of a component will be at or near the mold wall temperature and can be much lower than some distance toward the mid-plane due to the low N Fo that usually exists at the time of demolding. In addition, if the preheat temperature is not very high, the minimum in the state of cure profile is in the center of the component. 8 Since the temperature profile during heating in the mold decreases from the surface toward the center, more cure accumulates near the surface as the press cure proceeds. As the convection coefficient is increased, the press cure time must increase to balance the decrease in accumulated cure attained in the center of the component from the cooling cycle. Longer press cure times confer more accumulated cure near the surface of the component. If the mold is operated at a temperature equal to T ref then the accumulation of cure at the surface is in real time whereas at locations with lower temperatures, cure accumulates much more slowly according to equation (6). Since the profile of equivalent cure tends to be decreasing toward the center and the center must achieve at least Q target, the average state of cure will tend to increase with faster cooling rates.

caption.p: Average state of cure versus convection coefficient for T preheat = 43°C, Q target = 6 min, and T ∞ = 27°C. Component thickness is denoted in the legend. Q target: target cure; T preheat: preheat temperature; T ∞: bulk fluid temperature.

Fraction of total cure attained in the press at location of minimum state of cure versus convection coefficient for T preheat = 43°C, Q target = 6 min, and T ∞ = 27°C. Component thickness is denoted in the legend. Q target: target cure; T preheat: preheat temperature; T ∞: bulk fluid temperature

sec.p: It is possible to reduce the average accumulated cure by choosing an appropriate preheat temperature as shown in Figure 5. As noted, for some values of h conv the curves stop at an intermediate preheat temperature due to sufficient cure being accumulated during cooling directly from the uniform preheat temperature without any time in the mold. The reduction in Q avg depends on the convection coefficient for cooling such that a minimum occurs which gives an average state of cure very close to the target cure. A lower h conv is beneficial in being able to impart a relatively uniform cure distribution with a reasonable value of T preheat, whereas higher cooling rates cause an increase in the preheat temperature necessary to minimize the Q avg. Of course, from the viewpoint of practical molding operations, a lower T preheat is desirable both from a compound handling standpoint as well as scorch safety, but the press cure time will necessarily increase as T preheat is decreased. The T preheat to achieve the minimum in average cure may be prohibitively high in many practical cases, however.

caption.p: Average cure normalized by Q target versus preheat temperature (T preheat) for various values of h conv are denoted in the legend, where Q target = 6 min, h = 2.54 cm, and T ∞ = 27°C. h: component thickness; h conv: convective heat transfer coefficient; Q target: target cure; T preheat: preheat temperature; T ∞: bulk fluid temperature.

In a practical molding environment, it is likely that the airflow around a component and the ambient air temperature are not well-controlled process variables. It is therefore instructive to examine the effect of this potential variation on the minimum cure attained and the average state of cure in the component. The effect of variation in the ambient air temperature is expected to be different than that found for variation in the convection coefficient. If the cooling process is crudely approximated as that of a lumped capacitance system and ∂T/∂t at any given time is taken as the variable of interest, the sensitivity of this variable to h conv and T ∞ can be approximated. The sensitivities (θ i) thus obtained are given in equations (7) and (8), where τ is the time constant of the lumped capacitance model:

The sensitivity due to ambient temperature is exponential in time, whereas the sensitivity due to the convection coefficient changes sign at t = τ. Since there are time-dependent differences between these two sensitivities and the extension from variation in rate of temperature change in this crude approximation to that of state of cure in a component is not evident, simulation of the effects is warranted.

The effect of variation of the convection coefficient is considered first, assuming no variation in the bulk fluid temperature. The simulations were carried out by initially determining the t press required to have a correct cure cycle for a given value of h conv, denoted the “design value” of h conv. The press cure time was then held constant and the convection coefficient was varied above and below the design value of h conv. The process was repeated for a total of five different design values of h conv and five values of component thickness. The effect of this variation on the minimum cure attained in the component is shown in Figure 6. The points plotted in each set of five points represent the set of multipliers of the design value of h conv (0.5, 0.75, 1.0, 1.25, 1.5) and cover the range of component thicknesses from h = 0.635 cm to h = 8.57 cm.

caption.p: Minimum cure versus h conv for h = 2.54 cm, Q target = 6 min, and T preheat = 43°C. Press cure time established for center value of h conv in each cluster of five points. h: component thickness; h conv: convective heat transfer coefficient; Q target: target cure; T preheat: preheat temperature.

sec.p: There is a significant amount of potential variation in Q min attained within a component if the cooling environment is a typical free convection environment. Using the typical value of h conv = 20 W/(m2 °C) as a point of reference, an increase in the convection coefficient (or a decrease in the ambient temperature) will cause the minimum state of cure to decrease well below the target value. The sensitivity of Q min to the deviation of h conv from the design value is diminished significantly if the design condition is such that the cooling rate is accelerated. Thus, from the process control point of view, fast cooling via forced convection with air or water is beneficial. An unexpected result of Figure 6 is that the variation in Q min is essentially independent of the component thickness across the entire range of convection coefficients considered.

The variation in the convection coefficient also affects the average state of cure in a component as shown in Figure 7. It is apparent that for all three component thicknesses, the variation in Q avg due to changes in h conv is much smaller for higher design values of h conv and the results are consistent with those of Figure 6 where the state of cure is almost independent of variation in h conv for highly forced cooling conditions. As expected there are differences in Q avg among the different geometries which increase as the cooling rate is increased and more accumulated cure is required of the press cure. Thus, it appears that high cooling rates are beneficial for molding test samples or precision components where it is important to have close control over the state of cure in an article. Of course, as the cooling rate is increased there is the concomitant requirement of longer press cure times. The longer press cures may be able to be offset by an increase in the preheat temperature if the compound and process can tolerate elevated temperature preheats. Increased preheat temperatures have the added benefit of providing a more uniform state of cure distribution within the component 8 but may also add a source of potential variation to the process.

caption.p: Average cure versus h conv for h = 2.54 cm, Q target = 6 min, and T preheat = 43°C. Press cure time established for center value of h conv in each cluster of five points. h: component thickness; h conv: convective heat transfer coefficient; Q target: target cure; T preheat: preheat temperature.

sec.p: A similar analysis was performed, whereby the t press required for the design value of T ∞ was first determined and then the T ∞ was varied above and below this value to determine the effect on the state of cure distribution. Figure 8 shows the Q min attained versus the h conv for various values of T ∞. It is apparent from Figure 8 that for the thin geometry as cooling rates increase, the Q min approaches the target value of 6 min for all T ∞ values considered. The Q min values for the thin geometry have been (for convenience only) divided by a factor of 2 to separate the curves in Figure 8. Thus, in the case of the thin geometry, forced cooling is effective in reducing variation in the Q min within the component. This is not true for the thick geometry, however. Higher cooling rates still reduce potential variation due to changes in T ∞, but for nondesign values of T ∞ the Q min does not tend toward the target value as the h conv is increased. Thus, fast cooling cannot be used to ensure that correct attainment of Q target under variable ambient temperature conditions in the case of thick components due to the introduction of systematic error from variation in T ∞. The systematic error does not appear when the average state of cure is considered (Figure 9). The variation in Q avg is small for the moderate to high cooling rates and all curves tend toward the same value at high h conv.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: The required press cure time is found to be essentially independent of the convection coefficient for convection coefficients above 20 W/(m2 °C) and proportional to the square root of the convection coefficient below this value regardless of the component thickness. Variation in the convection coefficient from the value used in the design of the process will cause significant variation in the state of cure profile for low cooling rates with the variation decreasing significantly with aggressive cooling as the design condition. Variation in the ambient air temperature affects the state of cure profile predominantly for processes with low convection coefficients. Changes in the minimum accumulated cure occur due to ambient temperature changes for relatively thick components even at high cooling rates. More work is needed to incorporate other details of the cure simulation process such as multistage curing processes, accounting for the exothermic heat of reaction, variable thermal properties, and consideration of component geometries that are not one dimensional.
